children.subject: Don't really have a solution to your question op but im also in the same boat. Currently in my schedule I am tentatively planning on taking it Fall 2021 (first sem junior year), but if there is the same issue of no reserved seats my whole class schedule gets messed up ;-;

I disagree. 16b isn't a hard requirement for 70 because you don't need 16b to do well in 70, at all. 16b as a prerequisite is just a proxy for "you need mathematical maturity to do well in 70". Moreover, requiring 16b to be a declaration requirement would make people take longer to declare. This is pretty detrimental since you pretty much need reserved seats for CS majors to get into most upper-div CS courses. I understand where people who want to declare early are coming from looking at enrollment right now pretty much all seats filled up halfway through phase 1 and you might stay on the wait list forever if you don't have reserved seats (which you need to be declared to get).

Instead 16b should have sort out hiring TAs earlier and *not* offer only half of the 1000 open seats and just freeze the other half until they got themselves sorted. If the full 1000 seats were available at the get go, they wouldn't get a ton of confused people asking on piazza "I have reserved seats, and there's still hundreds of open seats, why can't I get in??!!"

If they didn't freeze like half of the available seats, people like me and OP would've gotten in by our phase 1. Also the university should stop taking our teaching budget away of course.

Agreed with Anon Comp, 16B + 16A should not be requirements for 70, they are not related whatsoever (besides that one hw with Sahai where some linear algebra was needed). I don't understand the idea behind why 16B has reserved seats for undeclared L&S students and force declared CS students to be stuck on the waitlist, the logic just doesn't make sense.

@Anon Comp and Scale I do agree with you and many of us have pointed out those same issues with the idea of requiring 16B before 70 (I took 70 without 16B and did fine, and don't feel like that affected me later on in UDs), but I think that is a different, pedagogical argument that faculty have pretty much made their minds up about. The thing is, right now 16B is not actually being enforced as a hard requirement, but students are still being punished alter on for not treating it that way. That's what I mean by just making 16B an actual hard requirement to prevent this (or, they can just remove the reserved seating as you suggest, but at this point it seems unlikely).

Ah, honestly I didn't know the policy was that you should take 16b before you declare -- that makes a lot more sense now, my bad. Thanks for the advice though, I do plan on sticking it out on the waitlist but hopefully if I don't get off I can take it next year.

@Anon Beaker - no problem, but just to be clear, I don't know that it is a policy to take 16B before you declare, but this page on the CS website says that you are expected to take it within your first 3 semesters at Cal.

Unless you don't have any good backup that you know for sure you can get into during adjustment period, I would just stay on the waitlist. And I would keep trying in future semesters if it does not work out. The policy seems to be that 16B needs to be taken before declaring, so now the right thing is being done by first letting seniors who absolutely need to get in. I'd expect that once they've given them a change to enroll, they'll work backward by class level (letting in juniors, then sophomores). So I wouldn't tell you to just give up trying to get in until you are a senior since it seems like they want you to take the course as early as possible (and many will drop the course in the first weeks for various reasons, as I had done myself as a freshman--regrettably). You should, however, make note of your situation, in case you do become a senior and someone tries to ask you "you had 6 semesters to do so, why didn't you take it earlier." It seems that these kinds of enrollment situations are just encouraging more L&S CS students to put it off until last minute because it seems pointless to try to get in before that.

A note to L&S freshman hoping to declare, especially since this remote situation might mean you are getting less help from peers/staff: take 16B before you declare, and don't drop it unless you are doing far more poorly than would be normal for you. And even in that case, just take it the following semester and declare during that semester or later. I was a perfectionist and felt like I was not doing as well as I had in my other classes (not doing that bad actually) and dropped it. I did not know what the consequences would be, I just wanted to be declared ASAP and take CS 170, get an internship with that, yada yada... Looking back, rushing to declare eased my anxiety (which is very important, don't get me wrong, and administration/faculty should not laugh at the anxiety caused for L&S CS students to declare), but did not make a practical difference in enrollment/getting a summer job (it turned out I could have gotten into 170 anyway, and I knew undeclared friends who got into other UDs too). If you get 16B out of the way, even if it isn't the most interesting/useful class for whatever you end up doing later, it will save you the stress of these poor seniors (might as well include my future self since I am not close to the front of the WL), and it will also help save room for others in later semesters. 

I do hope they just make 16B a declaration requirement or make it a hard prerequisite for CS 70, instead of just citing a couple of emails/bullet points on some web page/faculty anecdotes that urge students to take it before declaring for pedagogical reasons. It is clear that new, excited students at UCB formulate their own ideas about courses they want to take/when, and do not like being told (on top of the 3-course declaration requirement which is already a lot!) when to take what (isn't the will to explore widely different disciplines whole point of being an L&S student?). If faculty are upset that students are rushing to declare instead of taking their time with the LDs, they should just block enrollment early on, make them take 16B before 70, instead of blocking enrollment for senior students whose situations are far less flexible. This issue wouldn't even have existed if they didn't just make taking 16B before 70 a hard requirement to begin with.

if your lab section is full drop and re-add. being number 1 on the WL for a full lab you will be skipped and the people who are waiting on open labs will get in ahead. I was ~350 on the wl this semester and got in with ease but a lot of stress no way to get around that

history.content:
I'm an L&S sophomore CS declared. I tried to enroll in 16b during my phase 1 -- no seats available during my phase 1, and with enrollment closed off to the class I couldn't even waitlist. Phase 2 comes around, and there are 0 reserved seats for me still, so now I'm like 500th on the WL (no chance I get in). I thought we were supposed to be able to get into 16b as sophomores? But instead there's over 100 reserved seats for 2nd semester seniors (who I presume already enrolled) with 0 for L&S CS sophomores (that are left, anyways). That's fine, I understand enrollment is pretty constrained this semester and the instructors are doing the best they can. But I'm trying to figure out when I'll ever be able to take the class so that I can plan out my future schedule.

If this trend will continue, will I only be able to get into the class as a 2nd semester senior? Since juniors don't have any enrollment priority and it seems those are the only reserved seats I'll qualify for in semesters after this. Is it possible to get into the class in the fall, even if I'm a junior who won't qualify for any reserved seats (I've heard it's easier to enroll in the fall)? Thanks for any insight.
history.subject: How should I plan to get into 16b in the future?
